title: Reinhard Wenskus
text:
Reinhard Wenskus (10 March 1916 – 5 July 2002) was a German historian who was Professor of Medieval History at the <a href="University%20of%20G%C3%B6ttingen">University of Göttingen</a>. His theories on the identity of <a href="Germanic%20peoples">Germanic peoples</a> have had a major influence on contemporary research by historians of <a href="late%20antiquity">late antiquity</a>.
Biography.
Reinhard Wenskus was born in , <a href="East%20Prussia">East Prussia</a>, Germany on 10 March 1916. After graduating from high school in <a href="Sovetsk%2C%20Kaliningrad%20Oblast">Tilsit</a>, East Prussia, Wenskus began working as a commercial apprentice there. He served as a soldier in the <a href="German%20Army%20%281935%E2%80%931945%29">German Army</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. After the war, Wenskus gained his <a href="abitur">abitur</a> in <a href="Hanover">Hanover</a> and subsequently studied history, <a href="ethnology">ethnology</a> and <a href="Germanistics">Germanistics</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Marburg">University of Marburg</a>. He received his <a href="PhD">PhD</a> in 1954 under the supervision of <a href="Helmut%20Beumann">Helmut Beumann</a>. Wenskus subsequently worked as a research assistant, and gained his <a href="habilitation">habilitation</a> at Marburg in 1959 with the thesis "Stammesbildung und Verfassung". He was subsequently appointed <a href="Docent">Docent</a> at Marburg.
In 1963, Wenskus succeeded <a href="Percy%20Ernst%20Schramm">Percy Ernst Schramm</a> as Professor of Medieval History at the <a href="University%20of%20G%C3%B6ttingen">University of Göttingen</a>. He became a Member of the <a href="G%C3%B6ttingen%20Academy%20of%20Sciences%20and%20Humanities">Göttingen Academy of Sciences and Humanities</a> in 1969. Wenskus retired from Göttingen in 1981, but continued to teach and research. He died in Göttingen on 5 July 2002.
Research.
Wenskus specialized in medieval history, particularly that of <a href="Prussia">Prussia</a> and the <a href="Teutonic%20Order">Teutonic Order</a>, and the history, <a href="historiography">historiography</a> and constitution of medieval <a href="Germanic%20peoples">Germanic peoples</a>. Throughout his career, Wenskus was distinguished by his emphasis on interdisciplinary research. In addition to being a historian by profession, Wenskus was highly learned in linguistics, archaeology and ethnology, and sought to use evidence from these disciplines as a way to get a better understanding of history. Along with <a href="Herbert%20Jankuhn">Herbert Jankuhn</a>, <a href="Kurt%20Ranke">Kurt Ranke</a>, <a href="Hans%20Kuhn%20%28philologist%29">Hans Kuhn</a> and Schramm, Wenskus was a co-founder of the second edition of the "<a href="Reallexikon%20der%20Germanischen%20Altertumskunde">Reallexikon der Germanischen Altertumskunde</a>", to which he contributed a large number of articles.
In his "Stammesbildung und Verfassung" (1961), Wenskus argued that Germanic peoples were not organized upon biological <a href="kinship">kinship</a>, but instead based their identity upon being led by small warrior elite who maintained the core tradition () of the tribe. He also theorized that the "<a href="barbarian">barbarian</a>" peoples of the <a href="Migration%20Period">Migration Period</a> maintained ethnic identities distinguishing them from the <a href="Romance%20peoples">Romance peoples</a>, and referred to this ideology of "barbarian" ethnic identity as "Gentilismus". Wenskus' ideas have been highly influential on modern understanding on "barbarian" identity. It contributed to the development of the <a href="ethnogenesis">ethnogenesis</a> concept, and the emergence of the <a href="Vienna%20School%20of%20History">Vienna School of History</a>.
